titleStmt.title: J. P. Sparks et al. to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG4210

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p:
To his Excellency Thomas E. Bramlet
Governor of the State of Kentucky,

Whereas a judgement was Rendered in the Henry Circuit Court, for $200= Against M B. Ireland. As the Security of James Guthrie on a forfeited Bond, At the September Term of said Court, And Said Guthrie has left for parts unknown, And no Injury having Resulted to any person or the Commonwealth of Kentucky, Therefore We the undersigned ^citizens^ of Henry County knowing the facts as above stated Most Respectfully Pray and Petition you to Remit and Release Said Ireland of the aforesaid judgement. Atty's fees & costs Excepted. This day of September -- 1863.

John F Hall
Jno W Burdine
J. D. Gardner
W. Bensinger
John S. Clark
Jno W Burdine
T. J. Sparks
R. C. Lindsey
J A Reed
Robt Montgomery
Jesse P. Hill
E. R. Wilson
M Adams
M B Pearce
Thos Williams
W E Berryman
Nichael Lemaster
Thos W Robertson
H Ellis
L. P. Owens
I N Webb
Geo. T. Hamstan
W. J. Brewer
Thos Pearce, Sr.
Edwd S Farnas
Wm Peach
G. M. Hill
W. A. Lawrence
Thos J. Hall
Isaac Banta
F. R. Lyle
W. J. Maunts
C. Bergen
H. C. Thompson
A.. P.. Hughes
John Bush
J O Willhite
E W Easly
Jas Neale
J. S. Neale
Jno Long
Arthur Merlin
Geo Burgan
G.. H. Wills
John W Brewer

Henry Cir Ct
vs
M. B. Ireland

Remit all except fees & costs
Tho. E. Bramlette
Govr. of Ky
This remission is done not on any merit shown by Petitioners but upon the merit of J. P. Sparks who personally urges the same
